createEvent.title: Create event
createEvent.eventDescription: You are on the page for creating a new event. Here you need to set up its type, name and description. Set up a clicker image and set up one or more conditions for its end.

eventType.donationDesc: Collect donations for a specific cause or person. Perfect for charity events and personal fundraising.
eventType.fundraisingDesc: Raise funds for a project or organization. Great for community initiatives and non-profit campaigns.
eventType.jackpotDesc: Create a prize pool where participants can win rewards. Ideal for contests and giveaways.

eventTypeSection.recipientDescription: This type of event requires a recipient. Select the recipient in the field above:

eventEndConditionsSection.endConditionsDesc: Create one or more groups of conditions! The event will end as soon as one of the groups of conditions is met.
eventEndConditionsSection.endConditionsDesc2: You can set the amount of the bank, the number of participants or the end time.
eventEndConditionsSection.endConditionsDesc3: Feel free to give each group its own name.
eventEndConditionsSection.groupDesc: To complete, the conditions of one group must be met simultaneously.

documentation.title: Help & Guides
documentation.welcome: Welcome to our guide on events! Here you will find an explanation of the most important aspects of using our platform and interacting with other users, as well as some useful tips.
documentation.eventTypes: Types of Events You Can Create And Participate In
documentation.donationDesc: A donation event is ideal when you want to support someone directly. Think of it as handing a digital envelope directly to a friend or cause you care about. The money goes directly from you to them once the conditions you specify are met. How they work will be described later.
documentation.donationPoint1: You'll need to specify who receives the funds
documentation.donationPoint2: Money moves in one direction: from you to them
documentation.donationPoint3: The recipient gets the funds once some of the conditions set are achieved
documentation.fundraisingDesc: Fundraising is your go-to when you want to gather support from multiple people for a single cause. Like a digital fundraiser, it allows many contributors to pool their resources toward one recipient, whether it's for a charity, a friend's medical bills, or a community project.
documentation.fundraisingPoint1: You'll need to specify who receives the collected funds
documentation.fundraisingPoint2: Multiple people can contribute to the same cause
documentation.fundraisingPoint3: All funds go to the designated recipient when some of the conditions set are achieved
documentation.jackpotDesc: Jackpot events add a bit of excitement! Everyone contributes to a common pool, and the winner is determined partly based on chance and partly on your share of the pot's total bank. It's like a friendly competition where participants have a chance to win the collected full bank.
documentation.jackpotPoint1: No need to specify a recipient in advance
documentation.jackpotPoint2: The winner is determined by the event's outcome
documentation.jackpotPoint3: Creates a fun, competitive atmosphere among participants
documentation.setupIntro: Ready to create an event? Here's what you'll need to set up:
documentation.setupNameDesc: Something catchy that describes your event
documentation.setupDescriptionDesc: Tell people what your event is all about
documentation.setupTypeDesc: Choose from DONATION, FUNDRAISING, or JACKPOT type
documentation.setupRecipientDesc: Who will receive the funds (required for only DONATION and FUNDRAISING types)
documentation.setupImageDesc: A picture that will be used as a clicker!
documentation.setupConditionsDesc: What needs to happen for your event to complete
documentation.conditionsDesc: End conditions are what make your event dynamic. They determine when your event finishes and funds are distributed. Think of them as finish lines or goals for your event. To finish and play the event, it is enough that at least one of the groups of conditions is met. The number of condition groups is not limited. Each group of conditions can consist of a maximum of three conditions: the bank amount condition, the number of participants condition, and the end time and date.
documentation.moneyGoalsDesc: Want your event to end when you've raised a certain amount? Use a bank condition.
documentation.moneyGoalsExample: For example: "Complete the event when we've collected $5,000 or more."
documentation.peopleGoalsDesc: Here we are talking about the number of participants.
documentation.peopleGoalsExample: For example: "Complete the event when at least 10 people have joined in."
documentation.timeLimitsDesc: Need your event to end by a specific date? Use a time condition. But you shouldn't choose too big an end date, otherwise users may lose their interest
documentation.timeLimitsExample: For example: "End the event when we reach this specific date and time."
documentation.combiningDesc: You can get creative by combining conditions. Here's how they work together:
documentation.combiningPoint1: Conditions in the same group must ALL be met (using AND logic)
documentation.combiningPoint2: Different groups work as alternatives (using OR logic)
documentation.combiningExample: For example: "End the event when EITHER (we've raised at least $10,000 AND have at least 5 participants) OR (we've reached our deadline date)."
documentation.findingDesc: When browsing events, you can narrow down your search with these filters:
documentation.findingPoint2: Filter by event type (DONATION, FUNDRAISING, JACKPOT)
documentation.findingPoint3: Filter by progress (how close or far an event is to completion)
documentation.findingPoint4: Sort events by name, creation date, or progress
documentation.participatingDesc: Want to join an event? Here's what you need to know:
documentation.participatingPoint1: The event must be active (not completed yet)
documentation.participatingPoint2: You need enough funds in your account
documentation.participatingProgress: Once you contribute, you can track the event's progress toward completion. The progress indicator shows how close the event is to meeting its conditions.
documentation.eventCompletion: What Happens When an Event Completes?
documentation.completionDesc: When an event reaches its conditions, a few things happen:
documentation.completionPoint1: The event status changes from "active" to "completed"
documentation.completionPoint2: No more contributions can be made
documentation.completionPoint3: Funds are distributed according to the event type
documentation.completionDetails: For DONATION and FUNDRAISING events, all funds go to the pre-specified recipient. For JACKPOT events, the system determines a winner based on random and users share of the pot's total bank.
documentation.behindScenesDesc: Our system automatically checks if events have met their conditions:
documentation.behindScenesPoint1: When someone contributes to an event
documentation.behindScenesPoint2: When an existing contribution is updated
documentation.behindScenesDetails: This ensures that your event moves forward and completes precisely when its conditions are met, without any manual intervention needed.
documentation.tipStandOutDesc: Use a clear, eye-catching image and write a compelling description that tells a story. Events with personal stories get up to 3x more participants than generic ones!
documentation.tipTimingDesc: Short-term events (1-7 days) tend to create urgency and get more engagement. If your event runs too long, participants may lose interest before conditions are met.
documentation.tipGoalsDesc: Start with smaller targets for your first few events to build a track record of successful completions. Our data shows events with goals under $1,000 complete 72% of the time, while those over $10,000 complete only 23% of the time.
documentation.tipJackpotDesc: For Jackpot events, remember that your chances of winning increase with your contribution size relative to the total pot. Making multiple smaller contributions over time can help maintain event visibility in the community feed.
documentation.tipConditionsDesc: When creating events, consider combining a realistic time condition with ambitious funding/participation goals. This ensures your event will eventually complete while still giving it a chance to exceed expectations.
documentation.getStartedDesc: Now that you understand how events work, it's time to create your own! Whether you're raising funds for a cause, helping out a friend, or organizing a fun competition, our platform gives you the tools to make it happen.
documentation.topUpBalance: How to top up your balance?
documentation.topUpBalanceDesc: To top up your balance, you need to go to the settings page and open the Balance section.
